I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Polytechnic Education Development Project.1  
 
2. 
The  project  will  improve  the  quality  and  relevance  of  polytechnic  education  to  support 
workforce  development  in  line  with  employers’  needs  in  five  priority  industry  subsectors 
identified  as  critical  to  the  success  of  the  government’s  Master  Plan  for  Acceleration  and 
Expansion of Indonesia’s Economic Development (MP3EI), 2011–2025. The project will support 
key  policy  reforms  to  strengthen  polytechnic  education  through  an  integrated  approach 
addressing  the  priorities  of  equitable  access,  graduate  employment  outcomes,  subsector 
management, and study program quality and relevance.2  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
With the aim of achieving higher and more inclusive growth, and of expanding economic 
development  to  poorer  regions  across  Indonesia,  the  MP3EI  has  three  strategic  foci: 
(i) accelerating development in six economic corridors;3 (ii) improving national connectivity; and 
technology  capabilities,  which  are 
(iii)  strengthening  human  resources,  science,  and 
prerequisites to sustained, accelerated, and green growth. In light of current drivers of economic 
growth, investment plans, and estimated future industry demand in the six economic corridors, 
the MP3EI prioritizes economic activities4 to achieve a “self-sufficient, advanced, equitable, and 
prosperous  Indonesia.”  To  generate  broad  employment  and  income-earning  opportunities  and 
improve  productivity,  the  MP3EI  highlights  (i)  increasing  value  addition  and  expanding  value 
chains  for  industrial  production,  (ii)  strengthening  production  efficiency  and;  (iii)  promoting  an 
innovation-driven  economy.  As  a  basic  principle  and  prerequisite  for  development  success, 
human resource development is deemed a vital driving force for economic growth. Indonesia’s 
polytechnic  education  system,  which  includes  32  public  and  140  private  institutions,  is 
considered  a  significant  contributor  to  accelerating  the  shift  toward  a  knowledge-based 
economy and the development of a productive workforce. The proposed project will support the 
MP3EI  policy  objectives  by  improving  access  to,  and  the  quality  and  relevance  of,  the 
polytechnic  system  to  deliver  improved  skills  that  meet  the  needs  of  employers  and  the 
employment  aspirations  of  graduates.  The  project  will  provide  targeted  support  to  polytechnic 
institutions  in  six  economic  corridors  to  strengthen  their  capability  to  deliver  demand-driven, 
high-quality programs  related  to  five  main  sectors:  manufacturing,  infrastructure,  mining,  agro-
industry, and tourism. Assessments of investment plans and future demand lead the MP3EI to 
conclude that the demand for skilled labor will significantly increase in these sectors.  
 
Key  features.  The  project  has  the  following  innovative  features:  (i)  it  facilitates 
4. 
partnerships  between  polytechnic  institutions  and  target  industry  employers  in  economic

 2 

centers;  (ii) it  establishes  a  flexible  and  demand-driven  national  skills  fund  through  which  the 
government can direct funding to public and private polytechnics in the six economic corridors to 
contribute  to  achieving  MP3EI  objectives;  (iii)  it  implements  a  credit  transfer  system  and 
recognition  of  prior  learning  in  the  Indonesian  Qualifications  Framework  (IQF);  and  (iv)  it 
introduces a competitive mechanism and fosters an entrepreneurial culture, which will enhance 
management capacity and create ownership in the project polytechnics. 
 
5. 
Improving  skills  in  the  labor  market.  Macroeconomic  and  political stability  has  freed 
Indonesia  to  perform  impressively  over  the  past  10  years.  Gross  domestic  product  growth 
accelerated  to  6.5%  in  2011,  with  further  acceleration  forecasted  for  2012–2014.  While 
Indonesia’s economy is becoming more complex, shifting toward knowledge-based activity, the 
need  for  human  resources  with  advanced  technological,  administrative,  and  managerial  skills 
has become more pressing than ever. As a middle-income country, Indonesia is operating in an 
increasingly  competitive  global  economy.  To  remain  viable  and  create  additional  employment, 
enterprises  need  to  improve  service  standards,  produce  better  products,  improve  work 
organization  and  technology  use,  and  build  value  chains  that  increase  local  content  and 
otherwise capture value throughout the economy. However, an estimated 75% of jobholders in 
Indonesia  could  improve  enterprise  productivity  if  they  had  better  technical  skills.  Training  is 
difficult  because  90%  of  workers  throughout  Indonesia  are  employed  by  micro  and  small 
enterprises employing fewer than six workers.5 While formal unemployment declined to 6.6% in 
August 2011, an estimated third of the workforce is underemployed, and 60% of the employed 
population  works 
low 
competitiveness is considered a key constraint on growth and caused primarily by low skills and 
low productivity in the workforce. The need for advanced skills has been identified by industry 
associations in each of the five economic sectors to be supported under the project as critical to 
the success of growth plans.6  
 
6. 
Partnerships  between  polytechnics  and  industry.  The  government  considers 
expanding and strengthening the polytechnic system as a key strategy for upgrading the skills of 
the  workforce  to  better  serve  knowledge-intensive  and  technology-driven  industries  in  the  five 
priority  sectors  identified  by  the  MP3EI.  Currently,  the  country’s  172  polytechnic  institutions 
have only limited capacity to address growing demand for personnel with advanced skills. The 
government has therefore earmarked additional funds to establish new polytechnics and expand 
the  capacity  of  existing  institutions,  and  is  encouraging  the  growth  of  private  polytechnics. 
According to a recent survey by the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC),7 applications to 
enroll in polytechnic education programs exceed the current capacity of most public institutions. 
The study states that more than 80% of graduates from the high-performing public polytechnics 
find  jobs  within  3–6  months  after  graduation.  However,  feedback  from  employers  reveals  that 
many graduates need to be retrained as their knowledge and skills do not match those required 
in  the  workplace.  Although  demand  for  skilled  labor  is  growing  quickly,  many  graduates  of 
weaker polytechnics—most of them private but some public—search for 12 months or longer to 
find  employment  because  training  programs  are  outdated  and/or  suffer  poor  teaching  and 
learning  environments.  At  present,  a  common  challenge  of  polytechnic  education  is  limited 
industry involvement,8 which fails to correct the poor quality and relevance of training courses, 
and a lack of clear national standards to guide study programs and assessment. Many lecturers

of  weaker  polytechnic  institutions  have  little  workplace  experience,  which  makes  it  difficult  for 
them  to  prepare  their  students  for  the  world  of  work.  The  lack  or  obsolescence  of  equipment 
with which to simulate the workplace with practical demonstration and application hampers the 
quality  of  the  teaching  and  learning  process  in  many  underfunded  polytechnic  institutes.  To 
address  these  challenges,  the  project  will  foster  partnerships  between  polytechnics  and 
employers to jointly develop curricula to impart the skills needed in the workplace, create flexible 
mechanisms  with  active  industry  participation  to  regularly  adapt  training  programs  to  new 
business  circumstances,  and  prepare  flexible  graduates  who  are  able  to  adjust  quickly  to 
changing demands in the labor market. Study programs will be aligned with industry standards 
to enable industry to judge if graduates possess the skills that meet standards of practice and 
the  quality  requirements  of  industry.  Standards  to  be  adopted  in  the  project  will  be  registered 
with  the  National  Agency  for  Professional  Certification  and  aligned  with  outcomes  and 
descriptors in the IQF.9  
 
7. 
Government  plans.  The  project  will  support  Indonesia’s  economic  development  as  
detailed  in  the  MP3EI  by  increasing  the  supply  of  highly  skilled  workers  in  five  sectors  of  the 
economy. This will be facilitated by improving links between polytechnics and enterprises. Well-
educated  technicians  are  essential  to  enabling  the  transition  to  higher-technology  jobs  and 
increasing  the  value  of  production.  Striving  for  higher  productivity  and  competitiveness,  the 
government has strengthened its emphasis on developing technical and vocational education in 
general, which is reflected in enhanced investments in polytechnic education as stipulated in the 
MOEC’s  strategic  plan,  2010–2014.  The  project  will  help  the  Directorate  General  for  Higher 
Education  (DGHE)  implement  an  integrated  approach  to  improve  the  quality  of  polytechnic 
study  programs  and  skills-development  services  that  (i)  ensures  relevance  to  employers,  (ii) 
expands  access  for  vocational  school  graduates  and  others  interested  in  developing  higher-
level  skills,  (iii)  builds  the  capacity  of  teaching  staff  and  administrators,  and  (iv)  upgrades 
facilities and equipment to better impart to learners job-ready skills. The project will strengthen 
and  implement  the  IQF  to  support  quality  assurance  and  recognize  prior  learning  to  expand 
applicants’  access  to  high-quality  skills-development  services  available  through  selected 
polytechnic institutions. 
 
8. 
Link  with  the  country  partnership  strategy.  The  project  is  included  in  the  country 
partnership strategy (CPS) 2012–2014 and country operation business plan 2012 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and addresses four outcomes in the results framework. The country 
partnership  strategy  has  identified  strengthening  polytechnic  education  as  a  core  approach  to 
contribute to inclusive economic growth. The outcomes of the CPS to be addressed through this 
project  are  to  (i)  make  postsecondary  and  higher  education  more  efficient,  effective,  and 
responsive  to  the  needs  of  the  labor  market;  (ii)  improve  policy  coordination  and  the 
management  of  polytechnic  institutions;  (iii)  establish  a  strategy  that  develops  critical  skills  for 
national  development;  and  (iv)  increase  the  participation  of  employers  in  delivering  and 
assessing  polytechnic  training  programs.  The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB's  education 
strategies and with Strategy 2020.10 Project activities adopt the findings of ADB’s good practice 
guide for technical and vocational education and training.11

 4 

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

9. 
The  impact  will  be  the  polytechnic  education  to  produce  graduates  responsive  to  the 
needs of the labor market and contribute toward increasing productivity in the Priority Sectors. 
The  outcome  will  be  polytechnic  education  aligned  with  the  MP3EI  strategy  in  five  priority 
economic sectors. The performance targets are (i) the number of polytechnic students enrolled 
in study programs in the five priority sectors increased by 25%, with at least 30% of students 
being female, and (ii) the number of polytechnic graduates finding relevant employment within 6 
months  of  graduation  increased  by  25%  in  five  priority  sectors,  including  at  least  a  15% 
increase for women.  
 
C. 

Outputs 

10. 
The  project  will  deliver  four  outputs:  (i)  the  improved  quality  and  relevance  of  the 
polytechnic  system;  (ii)  expanded  and  more  equitable  access  to  polytechnic  institutions;  (iii) 
greater  private  sector  involvement  in,  and  promotion  of,  entrepreneurial  culture  to  strengthen 
polytechnic  graduate  competitiveness;  and  (iv)  strengthened  governance  and  management  of 
polytechnic education. To achieve these four outputs, the project will provide targeted support to 
13  polytechnic  institutions  in  selected  economic  centers  of  the  six  corridors  established  under 
the  MP3EI.12  These  selected  polytechnics  will  work  in  partnership  with  industry  to  provide 
demand-driven  examples  of  improved  quality  and  relevance  in  study  programs,  responding  to 
demand  in  each  economic  corridor,  so  that  these  successful  approaches  can  be  replicated 
across the country. The 13 project polytechnics will receive assistance to upgrade their learning 
and  teaching  environments,  as  well  as  staff  development  and  research  strengthening  toward 
their  becoming  centers  of  excellence  in  their  respective  economic  corridors.  In  addition  to 
support  provided  to  the  13  preselected  polytechnics,  the  project  will  establish  a  flexible  and 
demand-driven national skills fund (NSF).13 The NSF will provide a number of windows in each 
economic corridor through which polytechnic institutions can, in collaboration with their industry 
partners,  access  resources  with  which  to  upgrade  their  teaching  and  learning  environments, 
strengthen their lecturers’ professional development, and improve study programs in response 
to regional labor market demand and the objectives of the MP3EI. The project will provide $38.1 
million for the NSF. 
 
11. 
Output  1:  Improved  quality  and  relevance  of  the  polytechnic  system.  Under  this 
output the project will provide assistance to (i) strengthen standards and learning outcomes in 
collaboration  with  industry  and  align  revised  study  programs  with  the  IQF,  with  industry 
standards guiding the development and improvement of curricula to address skills requirements 
in  the  five  main  economic  areas;  (ii)  upgrade  lecturer  skills  through  programs  delivered  in 
partnership  with  international  polytechnics  and  through  industry  placements;  (iii)  revise 
accreditation, assessment, and quality assurance systems to improve the quality of polytechnic 
programs and ensure their alignment with IQF policies and guidelines; (iv) improve teaching and 
learning  environments  and  equipment  in  13  preselected  polytechnic  institutions  to  reflect  the 
skills industry needs; (v) actively engage and partner with industry to improve the quality of skills 
by  implementing  skills  development  activities  funded  through  the  NSF;  and  (vi)  initiate  the 
development of advanced degree programs in applied sciences and technology.  
 

                                                 
12 MOEC  has  selected  13  polytechnics  to  receive  special  assistance  from  the  project.  Appendix  6  of  the  PAM  lists 

them and describes how they were selected.

5

Output  2:  Expanded  and  more  equitable  access  to  polytechnic  institutions.  The 
12. 
project  will  (i)  introduce  innovative  strategies  to  improve  equitable  access  and  increase 
enrollment  in  high-quality  study  programs  through  short  courses,  distance  and  e-learning 
modes,  and  other  flexible  strategies  by  which  polytechnics  address  the  needs  of  selected 
industry partners in the five sectors; (ii) review access and equity policies to remove barriers to 
participation in high-quality skills-development programs and encourage lifelong approaches to 
learning  and  skills  formation;  (iii)  increase  enrollment  rates  in  five  priority  industry  sectors  and 
subsectors through the use of targeted scholarships to be approved by MOEC; (iv) develop and 
apply  recognition  of  prior  learning14  and  assess  at  least  12,000  applicants;15  (v)  create  a 
seamless  educational  pathway  with  multiple  entry  points  that  feeds  graduates  of  secondary 
vocational  schools  and  private  schools  into  a  high-quality  polytechnic  system  geared  toward 
acquiring higher skills; and (vi) fund strategies to ensure equitable access for women and other 
disadvantaged groups to high-quality skills development through the NSF. 
 
13. 
Output  3:  Greater  private  sector  involvement    and  promotion  of  entrepreneurial 
culture  to  strengthen  polytechnic  graduate  competitiveness.  The  project  will  support 
MOEC  in  strengthening  partnerships  between  employers  and  polytechnics  to  improve  system 
quality and responsiveness. Targeted assistance will be provided to: (i) establish an institutional 
framework  for  private  sector  involvement  and  partnership;  (ii) implement  training  programs 
relevant  to  selected  industry  skills  needs;  (iii)  enable  industry  to  support  the  delivery  and 
assessment of skills to build confidence in graduates’ skills; (iv) support demand-led projects to 
develop skills; (v) provide training to strengthen management capacity; (vi) help instructors learn 
to adjust training programs based on demand assessments and to incorporate entrepreneurial 
skills in curriculum modules; and (vii) develop strategies to foster apprenticeship programs with 
local industries. 
 
14. 
Output  4:  Strengthened  governance  and  management  of  polytechnic  education. 
Under this output the project will provide assistance to (i) conduct studies reviewing regulatory 
and  governance  frameworks  to  support  polytechnics’  improved  responsiveness  to  industry 
needs;  (ii)  conduct  and  facilitate  assessments  of  employment,  management,  and  financing 
arrangements to improve the efficiency of the polytechnic system; (iii) strengthen management 
and governance systems at polytechnic institutions through capacity-building programs; and (iv) 
strengthen  links  joining  polytechnic  institutions,  employers,  and  industry  associations  to  more 
effectively  address  industry’s  skills  needs  and  human  resource  development  plans  within  the 
framework of the MP3EI.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE  

21. 
The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  project  will  be  more  than  48,000  students  who  will  gain 
access to high-quality study programs closely aligned with the needs of employers. Employers 
will  benefit  from  improvements  to  the  quality  and  relevance  of  polytechnic  education,  as 
improved  skills  directly  link  to  improving  workplace  productivity,  product  quality,  and  service 
standards.  Improving  the  quality  and  relevance  of  study  programs  will  build  community  and 
industry  confidence  in  the  vocational  education  system  and  strengthen  this  pathway  toward 
expanding  meaningful  employment.  Greater  access  for  women  to  polytechnic  education 
resulting  from  initiatives  such  as  the  NSF  will  ensure  that  the  benefits  of  high-quality  skills 
development  are  shared.  Female  students  and  poor  students  will  capture  a  significant 
proportion of the direct benefits thanks to the project's gender and pro-poor targets detailed in 
the  design  and  monitoring  framework  (Appendix  1).  The  lecturer  development  program  will 
enable  39  lecturers  to  improve  their  skills,  initially  overseas,  while  the  project  supports  the 
development of a local master’s program designed to support the long-term development needs 
of polytechnic lecturers and instructors.  
 
A. 

Economic and Financial 

22. 
Economic benefits. Modernizing polytechnic education will contribute to improving the 
productivity  and  competitiveness  of  Indonesian  industry  and  promote  inclusive  growth.  The 
direct  economic  benefits  from  the  project  will  flow  from  the  increased  numbers  of  polytechnic 
graduates who find direct employment. Based on conservative assumptions, such targeted skills 
development  can  increase  monthly  wages  by  Rp2,000,000.  Estimating  these  benefits  over  20 
years and based on the total project cost of $92.60 million yields an economic internal rate of 
return of 17.2%. Other external benefits of the project that will most likely accrue to society at 
large, and not just the direct beneficiaries of the project, are (i) improvements in the provision of 
high-quality  skills-development  services  at  selected  polytechnic  institutions  filtering  into  other 
vocational  training  providers  and  thereby  improving  the  value  of  the  sector  to  industry;  (ii) 
improved responsiveness of the polytechnic education system improving the relevance of skills 
and  employment  outcomes  of  graduates;  (iii)  heightened  efficiencies  in  project  polytechnic 
institutions  resulting  from  improved  governance  and  capacity  improvement  and  regulatory 
reforms  under  the  project  supporting  other  polytechnic  providers  seeking  to  work  closely  with 
industry;  and  (iv)  improved  gender  distribution  in  polytechnic  institutions  as  a  consequence  of 
activities in the gender action plan creating additional choice and opportunity for women seeking 
employment,  particularly  in  the  five  priority  industry  sectors.  The  project  will  raise  polytechnic 
education quality, relevance, and efficiency in project polytechnics reaching 20% of polytechnic 
students.  

 
Financial  sustainability.  The  project  should  be  financially  sustainable,  as  the  bulk  of   

23. 
expenditures do not continue beyond the end of the project. Recurrent expenditures such as on 
equipment  maintenance  can  be  absorbed  using  additional  revenues  from  government  funding, 
student fees, and tailored training for enterprises. The project will increase the relevance of the 
polytechnic system to the labor market and improve the policy framework governing polytechnic 
institutions,  which  together  will  improve  the  sustainability  of  polytechnics  by  enabling  them  to 
better serve national social and economic development needs. Efficiency gains in the 13 project 
polytechnics  will  be  realized  in  part  through  increased  enrollment  and  the  resulting  higher 

8 

 

  

9

utilization of facilities and equipment. The government’s annual commitment to the project as a 
percentage  of  the  total  education  budget  is  projected  to  increase  from  0.03%  in  year  1  of  the 
project  to  0.7%  in  year  3  and  to  decline  to  0.03%  in  year  5.  The  government’s  annual 
commitment for the project is therefore deemed affordable.  

 
Governance

24.

have extensive capacity to carry out the project, as it has implemented numerous internationally 
funded  projects  since  1980.  The  financial  management  assessment  found  sufficient  capacity 
and  staffing  in  the  accounting  and  finance  section  of  MOEC's  DGHE.  The  Integrated  Chart  of 
Accounts  is  consistent  with  international  accounting  standards.  The  PMU  will  prepare

submit them to ADB, the Ministry of Finance, and MOEC. Of particular concern, however, is the

likewise  ensure  proper  monitoring,  particularly  of  the  activities  funded  through  the  NSF.  The 
financial management assessment questionnaire is in the PAM.

Poverty and Social  

Gender  and  development.  The  project 

26. 
is  categorized  as  effective  gender 
mainstreaming.  It  includes  elements  that  address  key  constraints  on  female  participation  in 
polytechnic education and includes a gender action plan. The key gender issues addressed by 
the  project  include  (i)  females’  limited  access  to  untraditional,  high-quality  skills-development 
programs; (ii) their access to technical training constrained by the costs of education and living 
expenses; (iii) lack of knowledge related to the range of study programs and career prospects 
for  females  in  male-dominant  skills  areas;  (iv)  academic  barriers  to  polytechnic  education  for 
lack  of  recognition  of  practical  experience  and  prior  learning;  and  (v)  inadequate  incentives, 
including  equity  strategies  and  scholarships,  to  encourage more  females  to  enter untraditional 
sectors.  The  gender  action  plan  includes  the  following  targets  and  gender-responsive  design 
features: (i) 30% of the short courses developed through the Project target the study programs 
that  benefit  female;  (ii) 30%  quota  of  the  internships  or  industry  placements  in  the  priority 
sectors will be for female; (iii) at least a 15% increase in female polytechnic graduates entering 
the workforce by 2016; (iv) 4,800 female students tested and certified to endorsed standards in 
the  priority  skills  areas  by  2016;  (v)  assurance  that  each  proposal  submitted  to  the  NSF  is 
evaluated  in  terms  of  its  contribution  to  gender  equity  and  achieving  project  targets;  (vi) 
allocation of 20% of project-supported scholarships to females; (vii) 20% of the lecturers trained 
being female; (viii) 20% of  the management and staff in the Project Executing Agency and the 
Selected Polytechnics Institutions who are trained on technical and management skills to meet 
industry  standards  shall  be  female;  (ix)  the  implementation  of  a  social  marketing  campaign  to 
promote  female  participation  and  mobilize  employers  to  recruit  women  in  untraditional  trades; 
and (x) the development of a gender strategy for the DGHE’s support to the polytechnic sector.
